title: Protocol for simulating foraging behavior strategy and dual-choice predatory sensory cue experiments in aerial-hawking bats
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Simulation experiment on foraging behavior strategy
Timing: 4–5 h/day for 10–15 days
This section describes the simulation experiment of the foraging behavior strategy, including training and formal experimental phases.
Training phase
Use cotton threads to hang bird specimens at different heights in the flight room.
Release all bats in the flight room and allow them to fly freely to detect the specimens. Once the bats can successfully attack the tethered bird specimens, the formal experiment can start the following night.
Note: See troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Note: In this experiment, a successful attack was defined as the use of wings by the bats to flap or directly attack taxidermized bird specimens and/or the emission of echolocation calls with a feeding buzz.14[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14],15[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]
Formal experimental phase
Place a planar star-shaped four-microphone array (Condenser ultrasound microphone CM16/CMPA, Avisoft Bioacoustics, Berlin, Germany) in the middle of one end of the flight room, with the central microphone at 2.1 m from the ground.
Place the other three microphones around the periphery of the microphone array, with each microphone 60 cm apart from the central microphone.
Ensure that all microphones are positioned at an angle of 120° from each other (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).

(B) A photograph of the on-site setup. In (B), since the high-speed cameras were placed 1.5 m above the ground in the flight room, the camera lens was thus tilted upward at an angle in order to cover a larger spatial area. Thus, the three bird specimens did not look at the same height in the on-site photograph, but in fact they are all 2.1 m above the ground.
In the large-sized flight room (9 m × 3.7 m × 3.9 m), tilt the microphone array upward at an angle of 20° from the ground (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Optional: Alternatively, if select a medium-sized flight room (e.g., 6 m × 3.4 m × 3.7 m), the microphone array may be placed perpendicular to the ground.
Note: In this protocol, we consider the main difference between medium-sized and large flight rooms is their length. A length less than 8 m but not less than 5 m is considered as a medium-sized flight room, and a length greater than 8 m is considered a large flight room.
Set up a high-speed imaging system (AcutEye V4.0, RockTech Technology Corp., Ltd., Hunan, China) in the flight room (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Place a high-speed camera approximately 1.5 m above the ground and align it parallel to the plane of the microphone array.
Place another high-speed camera at the same height on the opposite end of the sidewall.
Position four infrared light sources at the four corners of the flight room, approximately 1.5 m above the ground, in order to augment the infrared illumination (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Note: The configuration of the high-speed imaging system we used consisted of two high-speed infrared-sensitive cameras (MV1-D1312IE-240-CL-8, Photonfocus AG, Lachen, Switzerland), a synchronous controller (AcuteSync-20K, RockTech), and four customized infrared lights (KTJ-GY-300W-42V, RockTech).
Hang bird specimens in the flight room.

Hang horizontally one bird specimen (Bird 1) at 2 m in front of the central microphone of the microphone array and 2.1 m above the ground.
Hang horizontally two other bird specimens (Bird 2 and Bird 3) at 2 m in front of Bird 1 and 1.5 m apart from each other at the same height (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
During the experiment, randomly select one bat and place in the flight room for the experiment every night (between 2000 h and 2400 h).
Note: See troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Connect the microphones to a four-channel ultrasound recording device (UltraSoundGate 416H, Avisoft Bioacoustics, Berlin, Germany), which also connect to a desktop computer running the Avisoft Recorder software to record bat echolocation calls at a sampling frequency of 500 kHz and a resolution of 16 bits.
Use the synchronous controller (AcuteSync-20K, RockTech) to connect two infrared high-speed cameras (MV1-D1312IE-240-CL-8, Photonfocus AG) to the same computer that was connected to the ultrasound recording device to receive synchronous recordings of bat vocalizations and attack behavioral repertoire (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
Critical: In order not to interfere with the flight of bats and their ability to detect and localize the suspended preys, it is recommended to position the equipment either around the flight room or near the walls, away from the direction in which the bats are flying within the flight room.
Dual-choice acoustic playback experiment
Timing: 4–5 h/day for 20–30 days
Note: The number of days for this experiment includes an interval of 2–3 days between two randomly repeated experiments.

This section describes a step-by-step procedure for the dual-choice acoustic playback experiments by randomly broadcasting audio files in the selection chambers of the dual-choice experimental flight cage. We used two ultrasound loudspeakers (Dynamic Speaker Vifa, Avisoft Bioacoustics, Berlin, Germany) at each end of the flight cage to broadcast bird calls and silence playback files (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]). This experiment consisted of two groups: 1) silence vs. bird calls; 2) specimen + silence vs. specimen + bird calls (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C and 4D).

Reprinted from “Behavioral innovation and genomic novelty are associated with the exploitation of a challenging dietary opportunity by an avivorous bat”, Volume 25, Issue 9, 104973, iScience, Copyright (2022), with permission from Elsevier.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Download the flight calls of P. inornatus and Z. japonicus from public sources of flight call recordings (Xeno-Canto: http://www.xeno-canto.org/[href=http://www.xeno-canto.org/]).
Note: Convert the MP3 format of flight calls into the WAV format using Format Factory (4.5.5, Shanghai Geshi Network Technology Co., Ltd., China).
Optional: If the wild birds are obtainable, the calls can be recorded directly. The method is as follows: according to the induced vocalization method in darkness described by Lanzone et al. (2009),16[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib16] wild birds should be exposed to the acoustic stimuli of downloaded flight calls to induce calling by using an ultrasound loudspeaker (Dynamic Speaker Vifa, Avisoft Bioacoustics). Then, an UltrasoundGate 116H device (Avisoft Bioacoustics) can be used to record the calls of individual birds at a sampling frequency of 50 kHz and a resolution of 16 bits.

Randomly select high-quality calls from each bird and edit to generate two 10-s call sequences within their call intervals using the Avisoft SASLab Pro software (version 5.2.07, Avisoft Bioacoustics) (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2900-Fig5.jpg
Figure 5. Flight calls of two birds were used for the dual-choice acoustic playback experiment
(A) Phylloscopus inornatus. (B) Zosterops japonicus. Reprinted from “Behavioral innovation and genomic novelty are associated with the exploitation of a challenging dietary opportunity by an avivorous bat”, Volume 25, Issue 9, 104973, iScience, Copyright (2022), with permission from Elsevier.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
Note: Use Avisoft SASLab Pro 5.2.07 to measure the call intervals of the flight calls of two bird species.
Repeat the 10-s call sequences from the two bird species to generate two 3-min playback files.
Generate a 3-min silence stimulus as a control.
Place the ultrasound loudspeaker in the box slot outside each selection chamber.
Hang the bird specimens in the center of each selection chamber, 45 cm from the top of the cage (for the specimen + silence vs. specimen + bird calls experimental group; Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D).
Place the bats in the take-off spot (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Broadcast the audio playback files using the ultrasound loudspeakers connected to an ultrasound playback device (UltraSoundGate Player 216H, Avisoft Bioacoustics) after the bats were habituated (i.e., motionless and with eyes closed to rest) for 30 s.
Note: See troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].
Continuously broadcast the call playback files for 3 min and then stop; the playback sound intensity was 75 dB SPL re. 20 μPa at 1 m.
Critical: Trials for each bat were randomly repeated five times at both ends of the flight cage (Chambers 1 and 2, Chambers 3 and 4) with an interval of two to three days between two repeated experiments.
Note: See troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3] and troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].

Use two ultrasound microphones (CM16/CMPA, Avisoft Bioacoustics) connected to the four-channel Avisoft UltraSoundGate 416H (Avisoft Bioacoustics; sampling at 250 kHz) and the AcutEye high-speed image system (V4.0, RockTech) to simultaneously record the choices and behavioral and acoustic responses of the bats (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
Critical: Several nights before the experiment, individual bats were placed in the dual-choice experimental flight cage to acclimatize them to the equipment and the environment at their peak foraging activity from 2000 h to 2400 h.
Critical: The intensity of the bird call playback files needed to be approximately consistent with the call intensity of birds in the field; the intensity of the playback bird call files was measured by adjusting the sound volume of the ultrasound playback system (Avisoft Bioacoustics) before the experiment. A sound level meter (Casella CEL-633C1/K1, Kempston, Bedford, UK) was kept 1 m in front of the horizontal direction of the loudspeaker, and it was maintained at about 75 dB peSPL.
Critical: All devices were placed outside the flight cage.
Dual-choice visual presentation experiment
Timing: 4–5 h/day for 30–45 days
Note: The number of days for this experiment includes a 2- to 3-day interval between any two randomly repeated experiments.
This step describes the procedure of the dual-choice visual presentation experiment by alternating the hanging of bird specimens and changing the light intensity at each end of the flight cage (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]). We simulated the lighting conditions (including darkness, moonlight, and dim light) of bats when they encounter birds at night. This experiment consisted of three groups: 1) specimen + darkness vs. specimen + moonlight; 2) specimen + darkness vs. specimen + dim light; 3) specimen + moonlight vs. specimen + dim light (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C–6E).

Reprinted from “Behavioral innovation and genomic novelty are associated with the exploitation of a challenging dietary opportunity by an avivorous bat”, Volume 25, Issue 9, 104973, iScience, Copyright (2022), with permission from Elsevier.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1]
In the corresponding periods of different light intensities, use an illuminometer (accuracy = 0.01, Pro’sKit MT-4617LED-C, Pro’sKit Industries Co. Ltd., Taiwan, China) to measure the ambient light intensity.
Note: Measure the light intensity across multiple days and during multiple periods per day.
Obtain range values for the simulation experiment.
Note: In this experiment, they included darkness (0–0.02 lux), moonlight (0.05–0.40 lux), and dim light (1.50–4.00 lux). These values corresponded to the illuminance when the bats flew out after dusk and returned to their caves before dawn.
Set the 6-W remote-controlled intelligent LED table lamps (TL8012, Glonew Lighting, Shenzhen Glonew Lighting Co., Ltd., Guangdong, China) in the central position below each selection chamber of the dual-choice experimental flight cage 40 cm above the ground to simulate different light intensities (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C–6E).
Use the illuminometer (Pro’sKit MT-4617LED-C) to measure and match the actual ranges of the three lighting conditions (i.e., darkness, moonlight, and dim light).
Hang two bird specimens in the center of two selection chambers on the same side of the dual-choice experimental flight cage 45 cm from the top of the cage (Figures 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]C–6E).
Place the bat at the take-off spot to acclimate for 30 s.
Note: See troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Switch on the LED table lamps to illuminate the surroundings at the predetermined intensity for 5 min.

Critical: The experiment was randomly repeated with each bat five times at both ends of the dual-choice experimental flight cage (Chambers 1 and 2, Chambers 3 and 4), with an interval of 2–3 days between any two randomly repeated experiments.
Note: See troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3] and troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Use the AcutEye high-speed image system (V4.0, RockTech) and two ultrasound microphones (CM16/CMPA, Avisoft Bioacoustics) connected to a four-channel Avisoft UltraSoundGate 416H device (Avisoft Bioacoustics; sampling at 250 kHz) to synchronously record the preferences and behavioral and acoustic responses of the bats (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).
Note: See troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Critical: As with the acoustic playback experiments, each bat was placed in the dual-choice experimental flight cage from 2000 h to 2400 h every day to familiarize them with the experimental setup (no bird specimens were present at this time) a few nights before the start of the formal experiment.
Critical: The test bats were fed three to five superworms before the experiment to motivate them and enhance their desire to detect the target prey. See troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Critical: All devices were placed outside the flight cage except for the LED lights.
